lnseminaTion in The presence of chinese ink will reveal and mark The poinT of

of The enTrance poinT To cleavage plane.

Place some Nereis eggs inseminaTed 5 To 8 minuTes earlier in a Syracuse dish
conTaining alkaline NaCl (pH lO.5 To lO.5). Observe imm?gi?igly,The viTelline
membrane will elevaTe due To a sudden inhibiTion of jelly release Through The
membrane and a subsequenT accumulaTion of jelly in The priviTelline space. The
viTelline membrane remains permeable To waTer; swelling of The pv space is due To
colloid osmoTic pressure. ElevaTion of The membrane sTreTches ouT The sperm
enTrance cone beTween The membrane and The egg surface, Torming a long filamenT
which frequenTly causes marked indenTaTion of The mebrane. Eggs kepT in The
refrigeraTor may become polyspermic upon inseminaTion and show several of These
exaggeraTed cones upon TreaTmenT wiTh alkaline NaCl. WaTch The sperm moving across
The pv. space To The egg surface. RepeaTed alkaline NaCl TreaTmenTs may free
eggs of Their membranes. This meThod has been employed in isolaTing blasTomeres.
LeTer develQQmenT
Keep a sparse culTure of Nereis eggs going as long as possible To have an
occasional look aT The developmenT of The Trochophore larva. These will be
sTudied in deTail laTer.
 i CHAETOPTERUS
The polychaeTe ChaeTopTeru;,pergamenTaceus is collecTed in The muddy boTTom
coves of nearby islands. Each specimen lives in a parchmenT Tube wiTh Two
commensal crabs. Eggs are obTained simply by shaking an excised parapod in a
dish of sea waTer.  Sperm should be kepT "dry" by squeezing one or Two male para-=
pods inTo a dry dish and keeping The seminal fluid covered in a refrigeraTor. To
inseminaTe, add one drop of "dry" seminal fluid To IO ml of sea waTer; wiTh
anoTher pipeTTe, add 2 or 3 drops oT This "sTock sperm" To lO ml of sea waTer
conTaining eggs.
Freshly shed eggs are in The germinal vesicle sTage. Unlike Nereis, The eggs of
ChaeTopTerus begin To maTure sponTaneously when shed inTo sea waTer. Calcium ion
is necessary for This process, which has been sTudied exTensively recenTly by
GoldsTein. The maTuraTion process which begins in sea waTer becomes arresTed in
meTaphase of The firsT meioTic division. The spinule can be seen aT This sTage as
a clear area near The animal Pole. The eggs of ChaeTopTerus are highly pigmenTed
and granular, so ThaT liTTle sTrucTural deTail can be observed unless These eggs
are sTraTiTied by cenTrifugaTion. STraTified eggs in The germinal vesicle sTage
can be obTained by spinning whole parapods; laTer on, aT meTaphase of The TirsT
maTuraTion division, sTraTificaTion is more easily accomplished. For informaTion
on cenTrifugaTion of These eggs, see papers by Heilbrunn and Wilson. ln cenTrifuged
eggs, noTe The corTex and iTs granular compIemenT, The spindle (or The germinal
vesicle in earlier sTages), and The various granular layers.
ln observing The process of ferTilizaTion, noTe changes in The egg surface and
in The germ head. Can you see any? ls a membrane elevaTed from The surface? How
far?
